TITLE.P: Transparency and Accountability for Improved Growth and Services (TRACTION) — Malawi

SHORT_DESCR.P: The UK's Department for International Development (DFID) is considering fulfilling a new requirement in 2018 where we will be seeking partners/suppliers to implement the Transparency and Accountability for Improved Growth and Services (Traction) programme in Malawi. Any contract would be expected to start in early 2019.

This is a new five year Traction programme (with up to 24 month option to extend) that seeks to address accountability challenges that are severely hindering economic growth and undermining service delivery.

MAIN_SITE.P: Procurement process managed from DFID UK (Abercrombie House) with the requirement being delivered in Malawi.

SHORT_DESCR.P: DFID will contract through a competitive tender process for a single supplier (or suppliers if a lotted approach is adopted) to deliver the Traction programme in Malawi via the OJEU. There has been previous Early Market Engagement (EME) in August 2017 to inform the design stage with a further "desktop" “EME" planned for March 2018, this will be facilitated via the DFID Supplier Portal, with registration via Survymonkey. DFID encourages interest/participation from National suppliers with the appropriate capacity and capability. The the programme will take a highly adaptive approach. Pathways to success are likely to be emergent and therefore a deliberate, problem driven approach to programme implementation, with instrumental use of testing and learning, is necessary in order to navigate the complex political economy in Malawi. It is expected that between 6 and 8 issues will be targeted over the lifetime of the programme. Examples of issues the programme is likely to tackle include (but are not limited to):
— addressing blockages in maize (and other agricultural) markets,
— improving water supply in peri-urban areas,
— or reducing deforestation; as well as exploring issues impacting on growth such as trade barriers and negative consequences of the current tax regime.

These issues will be identified through research to be done in the first year of the programme. Differing from a traditional civil society grant programme, a combination of small grants (to different stakeholders), technical expertise, facilitation, and media and advocacy work will be used to drive change on chosen issues. Currently, 1 000 000 GBP has been set aside for a demand-driven flexible PEA fund to be administered by the supplier responding to requests from across the DFID Malawi team for analytical support.

INFO_ADD.P: Registration to participate in this “desktop” EME exercise is via the SurveyMonkey link: https://www.surveymonkey.co.uk/r/JC9RQLW
Deadline for registration is 12:00 on 19.3.2018; with the EME information available on the Portal from 20.3.2018.
Participation in this exercise will be facilitated solely via the DFID Supplier Portal.
Contract duration 5 years with potential option to extend by a further 24 months.
II 1.5 Estimated Total Value: This is likely to increase by time of Contract Notice due to inclusion of budget for 24 month extension option when known.

II.1.6 Information about Lots: Please note this requirement may adopt a lotted approach, the strategy is currently being developed. The subsequent Contract Notice will clearly articulate this in due course.
